verse: What then shall we say that Abraham, our forefather, discovered in this matter? If, in fact, Abraham was justified by works, he had something to boast about--but not before God. What does the Scripture say? "Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness." (Romans 4:1-3) NIV
reflection: The Jews were proud to be called children of Abraham. Really Paul uses Abraham as a good example of someone who was save by faith. (Abraham believed in God). Let us not look to our good works as a way to inherit eternal life.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, open my eyes that I might see glimpses of truth you have for me. Sensitize my heart and spirit to Your Holy Spirit's leading that I might be obedient to Your word. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: When people work, their wages are not a gift. Workers earn what they receive. But people are declared righteous because of their faith, not because of their work. (Romans 4:4, 5) NLT
reflection: What vs. 4 means, is that if a person could earn right standing with God by being good, the granting of that gift wouldn't be a free act; it would be an obligation. When some people learn that they are saved by God through faith they start to worry."Do I have enough faith?" They wonder, "Is my faith strong enough to save me?" These people miss the point. It is Jesus Christ who save us, not our feelings or actions, and He is strong enough to save us no matter how weak our faith is. Jesus offers us salvation as a gift because He loves us, not because we have earned it through the power of faith.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I thank You that my salvation does not depend upon my works because they are no more than filthy rags. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: David says the same thing when he speaks of the blessedness of the man to whom God credits righteousness apart from works: "Blessed are they whose transgressions are forgiven, whose sins are covered. Blessed is the man whose sin the Lord will never count against him. (Romans 4:6-8) NIV
reflection: What can we do to get rid of guilt? King David was guilty of terrible sins--adultery, murder, lying--and yet he experienced the joy of forgiveness. We, too, can have this joy when we: (1) Quit denying our guilt and recognize that we have sinned, (2) Admit our guilt to God and ask for His forgiveness, and (3) Let go of our quilt and believe that God has forgiven us. This can be difficult when a sin has taken root in our life over many years, when it is very serious, or when it involves others. We must remember that Jesus is willing and able to forgive every sin. When we remember the tremendous price He paid on the cross, it is arrogant to think that there is any sin too great for Him to forgive.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I pray that You would forgive each and every sin I have committed. I do believe that You paid the debt in full on the cross for my sins. Amen.

verse: Under what circumstances was it credited? was it after he was circumcised or before? It was not after, but before! And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while He was still uncircumcised. So then, he is the father of all who believe but have not been circumcised, in order that righteousness might be credited to them. And he is also the father of the circumcised who not only are circumcised but who also walk in the footsteps of the faith that our father Abraham had before he was circumcised. (Romans 3:10-12) NIV
reflection: Rituals did not earn any reward for Abraham, he had been blessed long before the circumcision ceremony was introduced. Abraham found favor with God by faith alone, before he was circumcised. Genesis 12:1-3 tells of God's call to Abraham when he was seventy five years old. The circumcision ceremony was introduced when he was 99 (Genesis 17:1-4). Ceremonies and rituals serve as reminders of our faith as well as instruct new or young believers. BUT we should not think that they give us any special merit before God. They are meant to be outward signs and seals that demonstrate inner belief and trust. The focus of our faith should be on Christ and His saving work not on our own actions.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I pray that my faith would clearly demonstrate my inner belief and trust in You. Help me to be a better witness of Your love and mercy. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Without weakening in his faith, Abraham faced the fact that his body was as good as dead, since he was about a hundred years old, and that his wife Sarah's womb was also dead. Yet he did not waver through unbelief regarding the promise of God, but was strengthened in his faith and gave glory to God, being fully persuaded that God had power to do what He had promised. (Romans 4:19-21)
reflection: Abraham never doubted that God would fulfill His promise. Abraham's life was marked by mistakes, sins, and failures as well as by wisdom and goodness, but he constantly trusted God. His faith was strengthened by the obstacles he faced, and his life was an example of faith in action. IF he had looked only at his own resources for subduing Canaan and founding a nation, he would have given up in despair. But Abraham looked to God, obeyed Him, and waited for God to fulfill His word.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, forgive me for my mistakes, sins, and failures. Give me patience to wait on Your timing in situation I can do nothing about. Thank You for having patience with me. Amen.

verse: Not only so, but we also rejoice in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; Perseverance, character; and character, hope. (Romans 5:3, 4) NIV
reflection: For first century Christians, suffering was the rule rather than the exception. Paul tells us that we will experience difficulties but they will help us grow. We can rejoice in suffering, not because we like pain or deny its tragedy, but because we know God is using life's difficulties and Satan's attacks to build our character. The problems that we run into will develop our perseverance, which in turn will strengthen our character, deepen our trust in God, and give us greater confidence about the future. You probably find your patience tested in some way every day. Thank God for those opportunities to grow, and deal with them in His strength.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I pray that you would give me the strength and the patience to deal with each trial that comes onto my life. Help me to become more Christ-like with each trial that comes my way. Amen.

verse: Before the Law was given, sin was in the world. But sin is not taken into account when there is no law. reflection: Paul was shown that keeping the law does not bring salvation. Here he adds that breaking the law is not what brings death. Death is the result of Adam's sin and the sins we all commit, even if they do not resemble Adam's sin. Instead, you will be caught and held in Christ's loving arms.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I thank You for the salvation You have provided through Jesus Christ, so that I no longer have to strive to attain perfection before I can be assured of eternal life. Amen.

reflection: In the church of Paul's day, immersion (in other words, a complete dunking) was the usual form of baptism. New Christian were completely submersed in water. They understood baptism to symbolize the death and burial of the old way of life. Coming up out of the water symbolized resurrection to new life in Christ. If we think of our old, sinful life as dead and buried, we have a powerful motive to resist sin. We can consciously choose to treat the desires and temptations of the old nature as if they were dead. Then we can continue to enjoy our wonderful new life with Jesus.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I thank You for the "New Life" that is mine through what You did for me on the cross. I thank You also that I can look upon my old life as dead, but alive in You. I thank You for Your mercy and grace. Amen.

Here Paul emphasizes that we need no longer live under sin's power. In our old life we were slaves to sin, now we can chose to live for Christ.
